text: <@UPV1HUCBH> We are testing several product market fits. So the website is different positioning than the google doc. I’m sorry if I was not more explicit about this, but we are simply testing language to see how people react. #startup :wink:

elements.text: We are testing several product market fits. So the website is different positioning than the google doc. I’m sorry if I was not more explicit about this, but we are simply testing language to see how people react. #startup

text:
<@UHWC9PXBL> Awesome feedback :thumbsup:
Let me try this:
Here’s Alice, she’s interested in backend development. The container-world, infrastructure and devops is a little confusing…after all Alice just wants to prototype an enpoint to upload a video, ML to detect what objects are int, compress it, archive it and return a storage url. Alice discovered Storyscript. She was able to describe her business-logic in simple terms and get the job done in minutes because the tooling helped auto-complete, the services were ready-to-use like libraries and no-plumbing deployments.

(not real code, just concepts to illustrate the idea)
```
when http server listen method:"post" path:"/upload" as req
    video = req.files["upload"]
    topics = machinebox/videobox detect input:video
    res = psql insert table:"videos" data:{..stuff from above..}
    video = someOpenSourceCompressor compress video:video
    storage put content:video dest:"/{res['uuid']}.mp4"
    req write content:"/{res['uuid']}.mp4"
```

elements.text:
Let me try this:
Here’s Alice, she’s interested in backend development. The container-world, infrastructure and devops is a little confusing…after all Alice just wants to prototype an enpoint to upload a video, ML to detect what objects are int, compress it, archive it and return a storage url. Alice discovered Storyscript. She was able to describe her business-logic in simple terms and get the job done in minutes because the tooling helped auto-complete, the services were ready-to-use like libraries and no-plumbing deployments.

(not real code, just concepts to illustrate the idea)

when http server listen method:"post" path:"/upload" as req
    video = req.files["upload"]
    topics = machinebox/videobox detect input:video
    res = psql insert table:"videos" data:{..stuff from above..}
    video = someOpenSourceCompressor compress video:video
    storage put content:video dest:"/{res['uuid']}.mp4"
    req write content:"/{res['uuid']}.mp4"

text: Alice had a JSFiddle-like way to rapidly prototype this but in a production-grade environment. Like Glitch, but open source and polyglot. But Zapier-like services are native libraries in our language.

elements.text: Alice had a JSFiddle-like way to rapidly prototype this but in a production-grade environment. Like Glitch, but open source and polyglot. But Zapier-like services are native libraries in our language.

text: <@UJKKBAMLL> i think this is closer by a lot, and way clearer with actual pseudocode (although alice’s use case could be more specific, ie, a really real world use case [eg alice wants to collect and save  data from cameras about what’s in stock in her company’s warehouse to make sure their just-in-time algorithms are actually making their wholesale business more effective]) but there are a few narrative parts i think i’d prefer more explicit (example: how these tools are possible because they exist in other disciplines, like FE engineering)

text: if you want to do a zoom or phone call i would love to talk through any of this—just DM me. i’ve done it with less exciting products and i honestly think messaging and documentation is the main thing keeping any of the ideas presented in this slack from taking off
